block.p: Caring for Children WEDNESDAY -- Kids of N.Y.U., a partnership of physicians, parents and other supporters of the pediatric programs of the New York University Medical Center, will hold its annual gala at the Pierre. The evening begins at 6:30 with drinks and a silent auction. Dinner follows at 7:30. Proceeds go to childrens' services and research and for renovations in the hospital's pediatric and neonatal intensive care units. Dr. Charles Lockwood, the chairman of obstetrics and gynecology at the N.Y.U. School of Medicine, will be honored. Tickets, $500, from (212) 659-9709.

Caring for Children WEDNESDAY -- Kids of N.Y.U., a partnership of physicians, parents and other supporters of the pediatric programs of the New York University Medical Center, will hold its annual gala at the Pierre. The evening begins at 6:30 with drinks and a silent auction. Dinner follows at 7:30. Proceeds go to childrens' services and research and for renovations in the hospital's pediatric and neonatal intensive care units. Dr. Charles Lockwood, the chairman of obstetrics and gynecology at the N.Y.U. School of Medicine, will be honored. Tickets, $500, from (212) 659-9709.

Lighthouse Boutique WEDNESDAY -- A preview of Lighthouse International's annual Posh sale of designer clothes and accessories will be held from 6 to 9 at the organization's headquarters at 110 East 60th Street (Park Avenue). The evening benefits vision rehabilitation programs and services and will include cocktails and hors d'oeuvres. Tickets, $100, from (212) 821-9300.

Developing Young People WEDNESDAY -- Fresh Youth Initiatives, a youth development program in the Washington Heights neighborhood of Manhattan, will benefit from an evening of Brazilian jazz under a tent at the Morris-Jumel Mansion, 65 Jumel Terrace (West 160th Street). The event raises money for the organization's programs, which include a food bank, a literacy initiative and mentoring. Cocktails at 6 will be followed by dinner at 7. Tickets, $75, from (212) 781-1113.

A Lift From Art WEDNESDAY -- An exhibition and sale of photographs and art at the Cornell Club, 6 East 44th Street (Fifth Avenue), will raise money for the spinal-cord research programs supported by the Alan T. Brown Foundation to Cure Paralysis. The event begins at 5. Drinks and hors d'oeuvres will be served. Tickets, $80, from (212) 944-8727, or $100 at the door.

Caring for the Elderly THURSDAY -- A black-tie dinner and dance at Terrace on the Park in Flushing Meadows Park, Queens, will raise money for the Ozanam Hall of Queens Nursing Home, which offers long-term care and short rehabilitation services to the elderly in Bayside. Drinks at 6:30, followed by dinner and dancing. Tickets, $200, from (718) 971-2200.

Support for Legal Aid THURSDAY -- Legal representation for the elderly, homeless families, disabled people and others will benefit at a fund-raising dinner for the Legal Aid Society at the Waldorf-Astoria. Lesley Stahl of ''60 Minutes'' will be the host of the event, which begins with cocktails at 6:30. Tickets, $500, from (212) 577-3346.

Dance Along the Hudson THURSDAY -- A dinner and a dance at Pier 60, Chelsea Piers, will raise money for St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital. The black-tie evening begins at 6:30 with cocktails; dinner and dancing to the music of the Alex Donner Orchestra will follow at 7:30. Lawrence S. Huntington, the hospital's chairman, will be honored for his service. Tickets, $500, from (212) 573-6933.

Victorians in Yonkers THURSDAY -- Victorian violin and piano music will be performed throughout the evening at a Victorian-theme gala at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers. Guests will tour the museum's current exhibition, ''Dressing for a Victorian Day.'' The event begins at 6 with drinks and a silent auction, followed by dinner and a live auction, where a pair of tickets to the 2000 Tony Awards and ball will be among the items offered. Proceeds go to the museum's education programs, exhibitions and community festivals. Tickets, $250, from (914) 963-4550, ext. 213.

Toward a Cure SATURDAY -- The American Cancer Society of Westchester will raise money for its research, education, advocacy and patient services programs at a black-tie dinner and dance at Pier 60, Chelsea Piers. The evening begins with cocktails and a silent auction at 7. Tickets, $300, from (914) 397-8816.

Soul Services NEXT SUNDAY -- The Marvelettes will perform ''Please Mr. Postman'' and their other hits at a benefit concert for the Institute for Educational Achievement, which is in River Edge, N.J. The school serves autistic children from northern New Jersey. The concert at the John Harms Center for the Arts in Englewood, N.J., begins at 8 p.m., with a cocktail and hors d'oeuvres reception immediately following the performance. Tickets, $125, from (201) 262-3287, or $25 for the concert alone, from (201) 567-3600.

Characters Acting MAY 22 -- Matthew Broderick, Sarah Jessica Parker, Camryn Manheim, Alec Baldwin and Eric Stoltz are among the actors who will take on unexpected roles at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers. The event will raise money for the educational and performance programs of the Atlantic Theater Company. David Mamet, a founder of the organization, will also perform, and William H. Macy, the actor and the other company founder, will be the host. The event begins with a Champagne reception at 6:30, followed by dinner at 7:30 and the show at 8:30. Tickets, $400, from (212) 414-1377.

Songs of Peace MAY 22 -- Broadway stars will salute peace and peacemakers at a black-tie gala at Carnegie Hall that will raise money for the programs of Seeds of Peace. The organization operates summer camps in Maine for children from regions of conflict, particularly the Middle East and the Balkans. Queen Noor of Jordan, Jehan Sadat of Egypt and Lea Rabin of Israel will be honored for continuing the work of their late husbands. Patrick Stewart will be the master of ceremonies. The evening begins with the show at 8. Dessert will immediately follow at the Essex House. Tickets, $250, from (212) 573-8040.

A Celebration for the Y MAY 22 -- The 125th birthday of the 92nd Street Y (at Lexington Avenue) will be celebrated with performances by members of the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater, Sheldon Harnick, Marilyn Horne, the Kingston Trio, the Guarneri Quartet and others. The black-tie evening begins with drinks and dinner at 6; the show starts at 8. A dessert reception will follow the performances. Tickets, $500, from (212) 415-5488.

Raising Standards MAY 22 -- New Visions for Public Schools will raise money for its programs at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria. The organization provides mentoring programs for principals, promotes improvements in math and literacy instruction and works to increase the availability of technology in the schools, among other programs. Stephen M. Case, the chairman of America Online, will be honored. Drinks at 6:30 will be followed by dinner at 7:30. Tickets, $500, from (212) 627-1000.

Leading Ladies MAY 22 -- The Ms. Foundation will raise money for its leadership, health and self-improvement programs for women and girls at a fund-raising dinner at the Grand Hyatt. Drinks at 6:30 will be followed by dinner and the 12th annual Gloria Steinem Awards at 7:30. Tickets, $500, from (212) 742-2300, ext. 420.

'South Pacific' MAY 22 -- A benefit concert of Rodgers and Hammerstein's ''South Pacific,'' at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center, 150 West 65th Street, will raise money for Lincoln Center Theater. The evening begins with the show at 6:45, with dinner at Tavern on the Green immediately following the performance. Transportation to the restaurant will be provided. Tickets, $1,000, from (212) 501-3251.

Images of Africa MAY 22 -- An auction of art and photographs of Africa by Herb Ritts, Peter Beard, Pamela Hanson and others will raise money for the village conservation projects of the Tanzania Wildlife Fund. The event will take place at 200 Fifth Avenue. Barry Humphries, as ''Dame Edna,'' will be the auctioneer, and a video will be shown of a trip of the model Christy Turlington to a Tanzanian rain forest. The evening begins at 7 with cocktails, hors d'oeuvres and a preview of the art, with dinner to follow at 8. Tickets, $500, from (212) 355-2232.

For Peace and Understanding MAY 22 -- The Tanenbaum Center for Interreligious Understanding will hold a lecture and awards dinner at the Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87th Street. At 6, the Boys Choir of Harlem will perform, followed by the awards and the lecture, by Jose Ramos-Horta, a winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1996. Phylicia Rashad will be the host of the event, which will raise money for educational programs of the Tanenbaum Center. Dinner will follow at 7:30. Dinner tickets, $500, from (212) 967-9874; admission to the program is free, but reservations are necessary.

Support for the Blind MAY 23 -- The American Foundation for the Blind will raise money for its programs at a black-tie awards ceremony and dinner and dance at the Marriott Marquis. The organization provides public education and advocacy on issues of visual impairment. Harold McGraw III, the chairman of the McGraw-Hill Companies, will be among those honored. The evening begins with cocktails at 6:30. Tickets, $500, from (212) 997-0100.

For Students of Dance MAY 24 -- A dance performance with students of the Alvin Ailey School and members of the Ailey dance company will be featured at a benefit for student scholarships of the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater Foundation. The evening begins at 7 at the John Jay Theater, 899 Amsterdam Avenue (58th Street). Following the performance, a reception with drinks and hors d'oeuvres will be held at the company's studios, 211 West 61st Street (Amsterdam Avenue). Tickets, $125, from (212) 767-0590, ext. 223.
